list.title: This Week
list.description: A selection of performances, events and other happenings in New York this week.

items.title: Rock: The Pogues
items.description: Although the Pogues, the rowdiest of the rowdy Irish punk bands, haven’t released a new record since 1996’s “Pogue Mahone” (which, incidentally, didn’t feature the frontman Shane MacGowan), the band reappears every year around St. Patrick’s Day, spreading a bit of riotous Irish cheer. With Titus Andronicus on Tuesday and Thursday and the Slo Gos on Wednesday. At 8 p.m.
items.author: Amanda Petrusich
items.ticket-info: $65 in advance, $70 at the door, sold out on Thursday

items.title: Film Series: The Films of Mark Rappaport
items.description: When Mr. Rappaport’s independent American features began appearing in the early ’70s, they were a long way from the granola aesthetic that would soon take over the movement, and these droll, deft, decidedly urban examinations of ordinary lives shaped by the extraordinary fantasies of popular culture are overdue for reappraisal. This series presents all of his features but one, mostly in newly restored prints, and traces the evolution of his work from experimental fiction (beginning Friday with “Casual Relations” and “Local Color”) to sharply insightful essay films (beginning Sunday with “Rock Hudson’s Home Movies,” “From the Journals of Jean Seberg” and “The Silver Screen: Color Me Lavender”).
items.author: Dave Kehr

items.title: Classical: New York Philharmonic
items.description: (Friday, Saturday, Tuesday, Thursday) The conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen got off to a fascinating start for “Hungarian Echoes,” his festival for the New York Philharmonic aimed at revealing connections and contrasts between works by Haydn, Ligeti and Bartok. The next program offers Ligeti’s “Concert Romanesc,” Haydn’s Symphony No. 7 and Bartok’s gripping one-act opera “Bluebeard’s Castle” with the mezzo-soprano Michelle DeYoung and the bass Gabor Bretz, with the actor Richard Easton narrating. A different program, featuring Bartok’s “Miraculous Mandarin” Suite and other works, begins on Thursday. Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m.; Tuesday at 7:30 p.m.; Thursday at 7:30 p.m.
items.author: Anthony Tommasini

items.title: Opera: ‘Boris Godunov’
items.description: The Met’s new production of this Mussorgsky opera is back after its introduction in fall. The sets are simple and traditional, though effective. The director Stephen Wadsworth draws detailed, compelling performances from the cast, led by the great German bass René Pape as the guilt-ridden czar. The Met chorus is splendid in an opera alive with agitated crowd scenes. Valery Gergiev conducts the Saturday matinee with Pavel Smelkov taking the final performance on Thursday. Saturday at noon and Thursday at 7 p.m.
items.author: Anthony Tommasini

items.title: Bluegrass: Steve Martin and the Steep Canyon Rangers
items.description: It’s natural to be skeptical of actors making presumably dilettantish forays into music, but the actor-comedian Steve Martin has been playing the banjo since he was a teenager, and his bluegrass album, “The Crow: New Songs for the Five-String Banjo” (40 Share), is a charming and accomplished effort. (Mr. Martin also made his Grand Ole Opry debut in 2009, and if that isn’t validating for a bluegrass picker, what is?) On Monday at 8 p.m., Highline Ballroom, 431 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 414-5994, highlineballroom.com; Sold out. On Tuesday through Thursday at 7 p.m.
items.author: Amanda Petrusich
items.extra-info: Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater

addresses.venue: Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater

items.title: Classical: Boston Symphony Orchestra
items.description: Without James Levine, who has faced the reality of his health problems and will step aside this September as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, these three Carnegie Hall programs are not as they were anticipated. At least two, however, are sure to be rewarding. On Tuesday the superb violinist Christian Tetzlaff plays Mozart’s Rondo in C, Harrison Birtwistle’s new Violin Concerto and Bartok’s Concerto No. 2, with Marcelo Lehninger conducting; the in-demand Andris Nelsons conducts Mahler’s Ninth on Thursday. Maurizio Pollini, who was to have been soloist in a fascinating program on Wednesday, withdrew some weeks ago because of illness. The tame replacement program, conducted by Roberto Abbado, offers a Haydn symphony, Bruch’s Violin Concerto No. 1 (with the reliably exciting Joshua Bell as soloist) and Beethoven’s Fifth. At 8 p.m.
items.author: Anthony Tommasini

items.title: Dance: Doug Varone and Dancers
items.description: (Friday through Sunday) Doug Varone occupies a slightly isolated spot on the contemporary dance landscape; although his work is varied, he is essentially a creator of dancey pieces that concern themselves with human relationships, and his choreography is charged with emotional content. In a new work, “Chapters From a Broken Novel,” Mr. Varone offers a series of episodic portraits, inspired by quotations from books and films and set to music by David Van Tieghem, which he will play live. Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m.
items.author: Roslyn Sulcas

items.title: Events: St. Patrick’s Day Parade
items.description: The author Mary Higgins Clark is the grand marshal of this year’s procession — the 250th — up Fifth Avenue, from 44th to 79th Streets, beginning at 11 a.m.
items.author: Anne Mancuso

items.title: Rock: Mark Kozelek
items.description: (Friday) The former frontman for the slow-core heroes Red House Painters and the current face of the like-minded (if gentler) Sun Kil Moon, Mr. Kozelek creates careful, quiet pop songs about dead boxers, railroad engineers and wide-eyed women. With Jennifer O’Connor. At 9 p.m.
items.author: Amanda Petrusich

items.title: Classical: Heiner Goebbels
items.description: (Friday) Closing Lincoln Center’s Tully Scope festival, this visionary German composer and auteur oversees the New York premiere of “Songs of Wars I Have Seen,” based on Gertrude Stein’s memoir of life in occupied France during World War II. Also included on the program is Mr. Goebbels’s “Sampler Suite,” which incorporates recordings of cantors from the 1920s and ’30s. Anu Tali conducts the London Sinfonietta and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment. At 7:30 p.m.
items.author: Steve Smith

items.title: Classical Music: ‘Guitar Plus’
items.description: (Friday) The guitarist and composer David Leisner runs this inviting series, which presents the guitar and its repertory in a broader chamber context. For the current program, “Bach, Shakespeare and Elephants,” Mr. Leisner is joined by the baritone Thomas Meglioranza and the Enso String Quartet for a program that includes an aria from Bach’s “St. John Passion”; Shakespeare settings by Elliott Carter, Daniel Pinkham, Peter Sculthorpe and Sibelius; Mr. Leisner’s own “Timeless Procession,” a setting of a poem by Rosemary Thomas about elephants parading past Carnegie Hall; and works by Haydn and Boccherini. At 7:30 p.m.
items.author: Allan Kozinn
items.extra-info: Leonard Nimoy Thalia at Symphony Space

items.author: Amanda Petrusich

items.title: Rock: Richard Thompson
items.description: (Saturday) An accomplished songwriter and guitarist, Mr. Thompson — who led Fairport Convention until 1971 — has influenced scads of younger bands, whether they know it or not; his unpredictable, virtuosic songs forged a strong path for alt-folkies everywhere. At 10 p.m.,
items.author: Amanda Petrusich

items.title: Theater: ‘Kathy Griffin Wants a Tony’
items.description: closes on Saturday. The flame-haired, torch-tongued stand-up comic brings her act to Broadway. Scabrous, profane and very funny, Ms. Griffin holds forth on the follies of American culture — which is to say pop culture — for two giddy hours, leaving a trail of celebrity roadkill in her wake (2:00).
items.author: Charles Isherwood

addresses.crossstreet: (between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue)

items.title: Events: ‘Art & Activism’
items.description: (Saturday) “Art & Activism” is the theme of this month’s Super Sábado lineup of free activities. The day will feature workshops in art, music and storytelling that incorporate culture with the drive for social change; 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.
items.author: Anne Mancuso and John Otis

items.title: Events: Latin American Arts Festival
items.description: (Saturday) A Latin American arts festival will feature music and dance performances, workshops, multimedia art displays, poetry readings and more; noon to 5 p.m. Part of the “Global Weekends” series. Free with admission.
items.author: Anne Mancuso and John Otis
items.ticket-info: General admission: $16; $12 for 60+; $9 for those 2 to 12; under 2 and members free

addresses.street: Central Park West at West 79th Street

items.title: Event: Introduction to the Language of the Qur’an
items.description: (Saturday) Bruce B. Lawrence, a professor of religion and director of the Islamic Studies Center at Duke University, will speak about the poetic style of the Koran and the translation of archaic Arabic into modern English; at 2 p.m.
items.author: Anne Mancuso and John Otis

items.title: Events: International Photography Show
items.description: Fine art photographs, as well as photo-based art, video and other media, will be on view at the Association of International Photography Art Dealers Show-New York. More than 70 dealers will be represented at the event, which runs through March 19 from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. and March 20 till 6 p.m.
items.author: Anne Mancuso
items.ticket-info: $25; $10 for students and panel discussions; $40 for a pass for entire show

items.title: Events: Irish Maid's Quarters
items.description: A look at the rarely seen living quarters of the Irish maids who once tended to the inhabitants of the house; noon to 5 p.m.
items.author: Anne Mancuso

items.title: For Children: ‘Disney Live! Mickey’s Magic Show’
items.description: (Friday through Sunday) You don’t need a fairy godmother — this weekend a theater ticket is enough to experience some of the transformations and spells found in Disney’s children’s films. In addition to Mickey Mouse and Minnie Mouse, this stage show includes characters like Donald and Goofy and Jasmine and Belle, participating in a host of illusions. Friday at 11 a.m. and 7 p.m.; Saturday and Sunday at 11 a.m. and 2 and 6:30 p.m.
items.author: Laurel Graeber

items.title: Film Series: Shinjuku Outlaw: 13 From Takashi Miike
items.description: (Friday through Sunday) The disaster in Japan will prevent the director Takashi Miike from attending this retrospective of 13 films drawn from his prodigious output — over 80 films to date. “Ichi the Killer,” a 2001 feature screening Friday at 8:40 p.m., is one of the director’s most notorious works, a blood-soaked gangster film that doubles as a sadomasochistic romance; his 2009 “Crows Zero II” (Sunday, 8:50 p.m.) is a sequel to a 2007 hit set in a brutal boys-only high school. Mr. Miike’s more lighthearted side is on display in the comedies “The Bird People in China” (Friday, 6 p.m.) and the children’s film “The Great Yokai War” (Sunday, 2 p.m.). The Film Society of Lincoln Center, working with Subway Cinema and Japan Society, is donating 10 percent of the ticket receipts to the Japan Earthquake Relief Fund.
items.author: Dave Kehr

items.title: Pop: Elton John
items.description: Fresh off an acclaimed collaboration with Leon Russell — their joint album, “The Union” (Decca), was produced by T Bone Burnett and featured Brian Wilson, Don Was, Booker T. and Neil Young — the inimitable Elton John is re-embracing his pop roots, rolling out “all hits, all night live.” (There are many, many hits.) At 8 p.m.
items.author: Amanda Petrusich

items.title: For Children: Purim Carnival
items.description: (Sunday) The Jewish holiday Purim has religious significance — it celebrates the heroism of Queen Esther, a Jew in Persia who saved her people — but it’s also party time. Carnivals surrounding the holiday (this year it starts at sundown on Saturday) honor both aspects. In its annual event the 92nd Street Y becomes Sushan, the setting for the ancient tale, with Purim masks, games, puppet shows and a costume contest. From 10:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.
items.author: Laurel Graeber

items.title: Dance: Martha Graham Dance Company
items.description: It’s been a few years since the embattled Martha Graham Dance Company has presented a significant season of Graham’s work in New York, so the company’s appearances at the Rose Theater are worth celebrating. One of Graham’s most celebrated pieces —”Deaths and Entrances” — will be performed on Saturday, along with a premiere by Bulareyaung Pagarlava. Robert Wilson’s 1995 evocation of Graham’s life and art, “Snow on the Mesa,” is on Friday and Sunday.
items.author: Roslyn Sulcas
items.extra-info: Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center

addresses.venue: Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center

items.title: Theater: ‘The Rover’
items.description: In this free staging of Aphra Behn’s 17th-century Restoration comedy, the audience follows the actors from spot to spot at the World Financial Center. The director, Karin Coonrod, is resourceful; the actors work hard; and the play seems like good material for the wandering format. Yet this marriage of art and commercial space feels forced, and the frequent interruptions prevent the work from casting a spell (1:20).
items.author: Rachel Saltz

items.title: Classical: ‘Music for Merce’
items.description: (Sunday) Beyond his role as a revolutionary choreographer, Merce Cunningham was also a crucial facilitator for the many experimental composers who fashioned works for his company: a point demonstrated by “Music for Merce,” an extraordinary new 10-CD boxed set recently issued on the New World label. Two shows celebrate the release, with works by John Cage, David Tudor, Takehisa Kosugi, Christian Wolff and others, played by an impressive array of Cunningham associates. At 5 and 8:30 p.m.
items.author: Steve Smith
items.ticket-info: $25; $15 for students, 65+ and under 30; for both shows $40, $25 for students, 65+ and under 30

items.title: Pop: Janet Jackson
items.description: (Friday, Saturday and Monday) In the late 1980s and early 1990s, Ms. Jackson was a mainstay of radio and MTV, peddling beat-heavy, danceable R&B-inspired pop (“Rhythm Nation,” “That’s the Way Love Goes”), while her sharp, abstract choreography inspired subsequent generations of pop stars. Lately she has been focusing mostly on her film career; she released her most recent record, “Discipline” (Island), in early 2008. For this tour she’s playing only her No. 1 records, and there are plenty to choose from. At 8 p.m.,
items.author: Amanda Petrusich
items.ticket-info: $59.50 to $250, sold out on Friday and Saturday.

items.title: Opera: ‘The Queen of Spades’
items.description: (Friday and Monday) Elijah Moshinsky’s highly stylized 1995 production of this great Tchaikovsky opera has returned to the Met with the powerful Russian tenor Vladimir Galouzine as Hermann, the dissolute officer with a gambling addiction, and the charismatic soprano Karita Mattila as Lisa, the vulnerable young woman whom the calculating Hermann desires. The news here, though, is the young Latvian conductor Andris Nelsons, who draws dark, surging and gravely beautiful, if not flawless, playing from the Met Orchestra. The mezzo-soprano Dolora Zajick sings the mysterious old countess; the elegant baritone Peter Mattei is Prince Yeletsky. At 8 p.m.,
items.author: Anthony Tommasini

items.title: Dance: Works & Process
items.description: It’s always hard to get a ticket to the Guggenheim’s Works & Process events, intimate previews of approaching dance, music or theatrical events, often involving conversation with the participants. The next event, a presentation by the Royal Danish Ballet — which arrives on tour in New York in late May — is a particularly hot ticket. That’s partly because the company hasn’t been here since 1988 and partly because its artistic director, Nikolaj Hübbe, is everyone’s favorite former New York City Ballet principal. The company will perform excerpts from various Bournonville ballets, as well as Mr. Hübbe’s new staging of “Napoli” and Jorma Elo’s “Lost on Slow.” And Mr. Hübbe will converse with John Meehan. Naturally both nights are sold out — but don’t despair! It will be live-streamed each time on www.ustream.tv/channel/worksandprocess. At 7:30 p.m.
items.author: Roslyn Sulcas

items.title: Film Series: A Tribute to Jack Garfein
items.description: (Sunday and Monday) An Auschwitz survivor, Mr. Garfein arrived in the United States as a refugee and rose to prominence as a theater director and acting teacher. He’ll be present on Sunday for a conversation following the 3:15 screening of “A Journey Back,” a 1987 documentary in which Mr. Garfein recounts his Holocaust experiences, and on Monday, he’ll be present for screenings of his two feature films, the 1957 “The Strange One” (6:30 p.m.), a tale of (barely) repressed sexuality and sadism in a military school, and the 1961 “Something Wild” (9:15 p.m.), starring Mr. Garfein’s ex-wife, Carroll Baker, as a kidnapped college girl.
items.author: Dave Kehr

addresses.crossstreet: (between Avenue of the Americas and Varick Street)

items.title: Classical: NHK Symphony Orchestra
items.description: Even before the news of the devastation in Japan, a rare New York performance by this excellent Tokyo-based ensemble, part of Carnegie Hall’s JapanNYC festival, was much anticipated. Now there will be new depths, and also great consolation, in the moving program: the autumnal, transcendent “Four Last Songs” of Strauss (with the elegant soprano Kiri Te Kanawa); Prokofiev’s inspiring Symphony No. 5; and Toru Takemitsu’s “Green.” The orchestra’s principal guest conductor, André Previn, leads. At 8 p.m.
items.author: Zachary Woolfe

items.title: Events: Broadway Musicals of 1932
items.description: (Monday) “April in Paris,” “It’s Only a Paper Moon,” “Night and Day” and other classic songs from Broadway musicals of 1932 will be performed by an ensemble of Broadway performers, including Christiane Noll (“Ragtime”) and Jeffry Denman (“The Producers”). The performance is part of the series “Broadway by the Year”; at 8 p.m.
items.author: Anne Mancuso and John Otis

addresses.crossstreet: (between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue)

items.title: Events: ‘The Middle East in Transition - Repercussions for Israel’
items.description: Itamar Rabinovich, who was Israel’s ambassador to the United States in the mid- 1990s, will lecture on the present state of Israel. Mr. Rabinovich, the author of many books about Israeli and Arab relations, is also a visiting professor at New York University and Harvard; at 6:30 p.m. Email fas.taubcenter@nyu.edu for reservations.
items.author: Anne Mancuso and John Otis
items.extra-info: Kimmel Center for University Life, Room 914
items.ticket-info: Free, but space is limited; reservations are required.

items.title: Classical: Bach Collegium Japan
items.description: (Tuesday) Masaaki Suzuki and his Bach Collegium Japan are devoted to the notion that Bach’s choral works should be performed by trim ensembles. When the group introduced itself to New York in 2003, it was with a “St. Matthew Passion” sung by a mere 24 singers: only three voices to a part. This time, as part of the JapanNYC festival, the period-instrument ensemble and choir offer the Mass in B minor. His soloists are Hana Blazikova and Rachel Nicholls, sopranos; Clint van der Linde, countertenor; Gerd Türk, tenor; and Peter Kooij, bass. At 8 p.m.
items.author: Allan Kozinn

items.title: Jazz: Myron Walden Countrified
items.description: (Wednesday) The saxophonist Myron Walden, for many years primarily an alto man, features his tenor playing on several new releases, including “Countrified” (Demi Sound), an album full of backbeat-laden soul and gospel. His live band includes the guitarist Oz Noy, the Hammond B-3 organist Ron Oswanski and the drummer Kenneth Salters. At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.
items.author: Nate Chinen

addresses.crossstreet: (between Park Avenue South and Lexington Avenue)

items.title: Jazz: Amir ElSaffar With Hafez Modirzadeh
items.description: (Thursday) Amir ElSaffar, an Iraqi-American trumpeter, collaborates here with Hafez Modirzadeh, an Iranian-American saxophonist, playing an improvised music that incorporates traditional elements of Iraqi maqam and Persian dastgah. They’ll be drawing partly from their recent album together, “Radif Suite” (Pi). At 9 and 10:30 p.m.
items.author: Nate Chinen
items.ticket-info: First set: $15, $10 for members; Second set: $10, $5 for members

items.title: Opera: ‘The Elixir of Love’
items.description: (Tuesday and Thursday) Jonathan Miller’s 2006 New York City Opera production sets Donizetti’s irresistible comedy in the American Southwest of the 1950s. The cast is classic City Opera: young, attractive and talented. The dramatically vivid, rich-voiced soprano Stefania Dovhan sings Adina; the tenor David Lomeli, in his company debut, is Nemorino, the bumpkin who plots to win her love. They’re joined by two excellent baritones: José Adán Pérez, as Belcore, and the raucously witty Marco Nistico, as the quack Dr. Dulcamara. Brad Cohen conducts. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. and Thursday at 8 p.m.
items.author: Zachary Woolfe
items.extra-info: David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center

addresses.venue: David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center

items.title: Events: ‘Art/Memory/Place: Commemorating the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire’
items.description: Opening Tuesday and on view through March 26, “Art/Memory/Place: Commemorating the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire,” an exhibition commemorating the 100th anniversary of the deadly fire of 1911 that killed more than 140 young women; the building in which the fire took place is now part of the university’s Silver Center complex, which includes the Grey Art Gallery. The exhibition, which includes material about the fire itself and the memorials that followed over the past 100 years, is co-sponsored by the gallery and the university’s graduate program in museum studies and public history. After a short hiatus, it will again be on view beginning April 12. Viewing hours: Tuesday, Thursday and Friday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Wednesday, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Sunday, Monday and most holidays. $3 suggested donation; free for N.Y.U. students, faculty and staff.
items.author: Anne Mancuso
items.extra-info: Grey Art Gallery at New York University
items.ticket-info: The events are free; exhibition, $3 suggested donation or free for N.Y.U. students, faculty and staff.

addresses.venue: Grey Art Gallery at New York University

items.title: Rock: The Allman Brothers Band
items.description: This archetypal Southern rock band is still on the road. Gregg Allman, the band’s keyboardist and main singer, is more than ever its center since its co-founder, Dickey Betts, is estranged from the group. His replacement, Warren Haynes, shares the twin-guitar passages with Derek Trucks, the nephew of the band’s drummer, Butch Trucks, and a jam-band leader in his own right. At 8 p.m.
items.author: Jon Pareles

items.title: Jazz: Charlie Haden Quartet West
items.description: Mr. Haden, the august bassist, has led Quartet West for some 25 years now, keeping a dual commitment to deep melody (e.g., romance) and restless elaboration (e.g., adventure). On a sweetly smoldering new album, “Sophisticated Ladies” (Emarcy), the group welcomes an honor roll of guest vocalists, including Diana Krall, Cassandra Wilson, Norah Jones and Renée Fleming. No singers have been advertised for this album-release engagement, but there has been talk of “special guests,” and you know what that could mean. At 8:30 and 11 p.m.
items.author: Nate Chinen

items.title: Jazz: Dave Douglas and Brass Ecstasy
items.description: Mr. Douglas, the indefatigable trumpeter, cornetist and composer, introduced his aptly named Brass Ecstasy a few years ago, most notably on his 2009 album, “Spirit Moves” (Greenleaf). The band — with tuba, French horn, trombone and drums alongside its leader’s trumpet — tackles originals and pop songs with equal bluster and flair. At 9 and 11 p.m.
items.author: Nate Chinen

items.title: Dance: Merce Cunningham Dance Company
items.description: Dances are always vulnerable to disappearance; memories erode, nuances are lost, details that characterized a choreographer’s work slowly fade. But even when you know that, there is a certain comfort in assuming that you’ll always be able to see the work of a master. That’s not necessarily the case with the work of Merce Cunningham, who decreed that his company would tour for two years after his death, then dissolve. And when the company, now in the second of those years, comes to the Joyce next week, it’s no exaggeration to say this might be your very last opportunity to see the spellbinding “CRWDSPCR” or “Quartet,” or the absurdist “Antic Meet,” with décor by Robert Rauschenberg and music by John Cage. (Actually, it’s probably your first opportunity too; until this month “Antic Meet” hadn’t been performed since 1969.) So no more reading: book! Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. and Thursday at 8 p.m.
items.author: Roslyn Sulcas

items.title: Jazz: James (Blood) Ulmer with The Memphis Blood Blues Band featuring Vernon Reid
items.description: The guitarist and singer James (Blood) Ulmer fashions an oddly hypnotic combination of influences: Ornette Coleman’s polytonality crossed with the psychedelic swagger of Jimi Hendrix. Here, as on a handful of recent albums on the Hyena label, he homes in on the blues, with a band organized by (and featuring) the experimental rock guitarist Vernon Reid. At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.
items.author: Nate Chinen

addresses.crossstreet: (between Park Avenue South and Lexington Avenue)

items.title: Dance: Mark Morris Dance Group
items.description: A new work by Mark Morris doesn’t arrive every day, but voila! Here’s one to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Mark Morris Dance Group. Set to Johann Nepomuk Hummel’s Piano Trio No. 5, the new “Festival Dance” will be performed alongside two recent works, “The Muir” and the all-female “Petrichor,” neither before seen in New York. Fittingly, the season is being held on the company’s home turf in Brooklyn, although the small performance space means that tickets will be scarce. Don’t wait to get yours. (Through March 27.) At 7:30 p.m.
items.author: Roslyn Sulcas

items.title: Theater: ‘The Hallway Trilogy’
items.description: A series of plays spanning a century of progress — or rather decline — in a Lower East Side apartment hallway. The middle play, “Paraffin,” contains some of Adam Rapp’s most sensitive writing, and all three plays feature exciting, across-the-board excellent casts. But still it’s the shock value of the various gruesome behaviors displayed that lingers (1:30 each play).
items.author: Charles Isherwood

article.title: ‘The Hallway Trilogy’ by Adam Rapp - Review
text: Spend a few minutes - or even a few hours - wandering the halls of your average New York apartment building, and you are not likely to see much more eye-popping action than the collecting of newspapers, the wrangling of children into chunky strollers and the delicate dance of polite avoidance that most locals consider all that is required of neighborly intimacy.

To watch "The Hallway Trilogy" by Adam Rapp is to enter an alternate universe. In this series of connected plays being performed in rotating repertory at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater (or in all-day marathons on Sunday), a nondescript passageway in a Lower East Side tenement building becomes a carnival of the desperate, the grotesque, the outrageous. Mr. Rapp, a relentless provocateur whose numerous plays have paraded a feast of bad behavior before the city’s more adventurous - and strong-stomached - theatergoers, never ceases to extend himself in the presentation of the grisly extremes of human experience.

"The Hallway Trilogy" contains some of Mr. Rapp’s most sensitive and mature writing, in the finest of the plays, "Paraffin," set on the day of the big blackout of 2003. All three feature exciting casts of talented young actors: Julianne Nicholson ("This"), Maria Dizzia ("In the Next Room, or the Vibrator Play"), Jeremy Strong ("New Jerusalem"), Katherine Waterston ("Bachelorette"), Louis Cancelmi ("Blasted") and many more.

But what is most distinctive and most memorable about Mr. Rapp’s new work is what is often most distinctive and memorable about Mr. Rapp’s writing: the gross-out factor. I never expected to see a man who has soiled himself strip down and clean up onstage. Or a pregnant woman’s water breaking. Attempted murder by machete? Maybe. The lancing of plague-ridden boils? Definitely not.

I can now say I have witnessed all this, and much more, thanks to "The Hallway Trilogy." For the last play in the series, "Nursing," set in the future, theatergoers are provided with germ-dispelling face masks. Air sickness bags would probably be more apposite.

"Rose," the first play, directed by Mr. Rapp, is comparatively tame, but then it takes place in 1953, and thus treats only the kind of outrageous, self-destructive behavior that "Mad Men" has made such a fetish of accentuating, namely smoking. It’s an intermittently appealing but often contrived comedy-drama about the colliding hopes and fraying dreams of the inhabitants of an apartment building ruled by an ogre-ish superintendent (the effectively repellent Guy Boyd). His alacrity at changing the locks of renters in a pinch gives Mr. Rapp a convenient excuse for having the play’s characters idling in the hallway for implausibly long stretches.

The super’s name is Eugene O’Neil, and a central strand of the episodic plot turns on this oddity. Rose Hathaway, played with a smiling fragility by Ms. Waterston in one of the trilogy’s standout performances, is an aspiring actress convinced that the playwright - whose death has been reported in the morning papers - has in fact falsified his demise and is hiding out in this run-down building. (The set, by Beowulf Boritt, precisely captures the borderline-squalid milieu.)

Nervous and perhaps just a little unhinged, Rose gets no response when she knocks on her idol’s door but lingers in hope, passing the time with the other residents of the floor: Orest, a cornet-playing Russian who cutely mangles the language ("I thank you from the basement of my heart"), played by a funny, poker-faced William Apps; the ardent young Communist Jerry (Mr. Cancelmi, excellent), who is obsessed with the comely Mary (Ms. Nicholson) from upstairs; Megan (period-perfect Sarah Lemp), Mary’s sweet-natured schoolteacher sister, who pines for Orest; and a silent fellow referred to as Marbles (a capering Nick Lawson) for his playful habit of dispensing these at whim.

Although Mr. Rapp’s dialogue often bristles with humor, only Ms. Waterston truly has a chance to shape a whole character, suggesting a sensitive heart and confused mind suffering underneath her character’s pert, ingratiating exterior. Most of the others either skirt stereotype or veer into unmotivated behavior: Would Ms. Nicholson’s poised, beautiful Mary, who came within inches of landing a millionaire, really give herself to her slobbish super with such casual carelessness? Would Orest move from friendly overtures to Rose to brutally cruel rejection of Megan so easily?

Mr. Rapp creates characters more grounded in truth in the contemporary play, "Paraffin," well directed by Daniel Aukin. The passage of 50 years has obliterated any appealing period details in the architecture, although the inhabitants are of the same slightly bohemian, aspiring middle classes. This more focused play centers on the strained marriage of the pregnant Margo (Ms. Nicholson) and her would-be rocker husband Denny (Mr. Apps), he of the soiled jeans, found unconscious outside the couple’s door as the play begins.

Denny’s younger brother Lucas (Mr. Strong), a veteran of the war in Afghanistan who is in a wheelchair, lives two doors down. Soured by his experience, he strafes anyone who comes within his limited firing range with sarcasm and abuse. The primary victims are his roommate Marty (Mr. Boyd, in happier mode), a middle-aged gay man whom he savagely ridicules for his affinity for younger black guys (Stephen Tyrone Williams is a charmer as the pickup); and Rahel (a flustered, touching Ms. Dizzia), a married Israeli woman living upstairs with whom Lucas aggressively flirts and then viciously taunts when she rejects his advances.

But Lucas reveals a more complex nature in the play’s moving central scene, set during the first hours of the blackout. Mr. Strong, who exudes a sullen poisonousness when his character is in attack mode, strips away the harsh exterior to expose the sad truth about Lucas. His anger has less to do with his injury than his long-hidden love for his brother’s wife. Ms. Nicholson is terrific too in this extended scene, confessing at one point that her life with Denny has become so troubled that she wishes she had never become pregnant.

There are also fine contributions from Sue Jean Kim, as Margo’s friend Dena, and Danny Mastrogiorgio as Kevin, the super, who has a shy crush on Dena. Mr. Rapp captures with an uncharacteristic depth of feeling the mood that overtakes all the characters in the liberating atmosphere of the blackout: the sense of being "stuck in our lives," as Dena puts it, accompanied by the yearning for change that may never be acted upon when everyday habits return.

The delicate pitch of this scene, the highlight of the trilogy, is light-years away from the preposterous dystopia of "Nursing," directed by Trip Cullman and set midway through the current century. The tenement hallway has become a "museum of disease and nursing," all infectious diseases having been wiped off the planet. Ms. Kim plays tour guide with the perky demeanor of a 1960s stewardess and the wardrobe to match, suggesting that we will still be recycling the same fashion fads well into the future. (The excellent costumes are by Jessica Pabst.)

The audience is cast as visitors who have come to watch a volunteer, Lloyd Boyd (Logan Marshall-Green, deserving an actor’s equivalent of the Purple Heart), be infected with various pathogens, including the Black Death and cholera - particularly fun, with Lloyd vomiting while writhing in pain from diarrhea on the toilet.

Mr. Rapp’s bodily-fluid-drenched gorefest pounds home the idea that while bacteria and viruses may have been eradicated, the disease that is mankind still wreaks havoc. But there remains a cadre of extremists who believe that fatal toxins need to be returned to the world so that people will again know suffering, and thus empathy will be reborn.

One of Lloyd’s nurses is among this radical crew (Ms. Dizzia, in a grim role), bent on liberating Lloyd and spreading the latest of his grisly diseases to humanity. To which one can only say - and not for the first time during "The Hallway Trilogy" - ugh!
THE HALLWAY TRILOGY

items.author: Charles Isherwood

article.title: ‘Black Tie’ by A. R Gurney, on Class Foibles - Review
text: There are not many fixed verities in the world of the theater, but one of the few is that when A.R. Gurney returns to home territory - writing about the manners and morals of the white Anglo-Saxon Protestant upper class - the results will most likely be gratifying. Mr. Gurney’s "Black Tie," which opened on Tuesday night at the 59E59 Theaters, is one of this prolific writer’s most enjoyable plays in years, a modest but effortlessly engaging comedy about the generational shifts in the subset of humanity Mr. Gurney has been writing about with warmth, humor and insight throughout his career.

Directed with a deft touch by Mark Lamos, Primary Stages’ production is adorned by a suave comic performance from Daniel Davis, portraying an exemplar of a certain class of man from the early-to-mid-20th century. He’s the father of Curtis (Gregg Edelman), who is the father of the groom at a wedding in upstate New York. Curtis’s dear old dad is also, strictly speaking, dead, although this does not prevent him from offering copious advice to his son about how a proper wedding is properly brought off.

Very little about the nuptials of his grandson strikes this most unquiet ghost as even remotely appropriate. The funky Adirondacks hotel might be fun for a weekend lark, but for a family wedding? Appalling. (John Arnone’s set is precisely observed, striking the right note of tacky, woodsy quaintness.) And what’s this about the bride and the groom writing their own vows? Even the term "rehearsal dinner," for which Curtis is trying to dress as the play begins, strikes his father’s ear with a shrill sound.
"How do you rehearse a dinner?" he sniffs in dismay. Once upon a happier time, the event was called the bridal dinner.

This paternal apparition appears to have been conjured by Curtis via a kind of sartorial osmosis. Curtis has decided to wear his father’s old tuxedo to the dinner, although Dad does not approve of this modish term, either. An ample dispenser of arcane information, Dad sternly tells Curtis that "we call it a dinner jacket," the word tuxedo having been coined rather too recently and spread to all classes of society with unfortunate haste.
"One of those bold New York gestures which caught on," he says. "Like brunch."

Mr. Davis, exuding the essence of easygoing gentility, brings innumerable witty inflections to his performance, investing single words with resignation, surprise and various shades of disapproval at the sad falling off of standards in the world. Even the pauses are rich with unspoken protest, or simple bewilderment, as when Curtis gently fills him in on the complicated racial makeup of his grandson’s fiancée, who is part African-American, part Vietnamese and part Peruvian.
"I’ll have to let this sink in," Mr. Davis says after an elaborate series of pauses, winning one of the evening’s biggest laughs.

The colloquies between Curtis and the ghost of his father constitute the play’s funniest and most appealing scenes. Mr. Davis is such a continual pleasure, dispensing tart bons mots by the dozen, that you might regret his frequent disappearances during the scenes in which Curtis interacts with his actually present family. (Mr. Gurney isn’t quite able to smooth over the awkwardness of these entrances and exits.)

But Mr. Edelman is fine company as the genial Curtis, as is the appealingly dry Carolyn McCormick, perfectly cast as Curtis’s forbearing wife, Mimi. She is of the same class and upbringing but gently pushes against her own hidebound instincts. She has noticed that her husband has been sounding strangely like his father at times lately, which is none too pleasing to Mimi, since she and Curtis’s father never got on well. She thinks the tuxedo - er, dinner jacket - is rather too formal for this evening’s event, too.

Curtis stands firm, even when their daughter, Elsie (Elvy Yost), makes wry jokes about Curtis’s being mistaken for a waiter. But real drama unfolds when Elsie brings news that a friend of the bride, an up-and-coming standup comic, has offered to perform a set at the rehearsal dinner, which will severely curtail Curtis’s opportunity to wax lyrical in the speech he has been carefully shaping with the input of his father’s ghost.

Curtis’s disappointment boils over into outrage when Teddy (Ari Brand) bursts into the room to inform his parents that he and his fiancée, Maya, have just had an explosive fight, with the supposedly snobbish behavior of his parents a central matter of contention.

This emotionally climactic scene doesn’t ring as true as much of what has come before. It doesn’t seem plausible that Teddy would be quite so forthcoming in detailing all of Maya’s many objections to his parents on the eve of the wedding. (Bad manners, surely, even from a generation more forthright about airing grievances.) Mr. Gurney might have felt the need to give his play a suitably pointed climax, but his style is most appealing when it is most gentle, and something about this scene of wedding jitters, with its confrontation and tidy reconciliation, feels forced.

Nor is it necessary for Mr. Gurney to gin up drama to give his light comedy some manufactured angst. Without the scene of family fireworks, "Black Tie" is insightful and touching in its depiction of a man welcoming back that ghost many of us have to banish consciously from our minds as we grow older, the voice of a parent (or grandparent) that becomes an internal barometer of the propriety of our behavior, whether we like it or not.

And then, for too much of this climactic scene, there’s the absence of the play’s most entertaining character - Mr. Davis’s friendly, admonishing ghost. He does at last make a welcome return, however, to give his son a final piece of friendly advice, one proving that underneath the seemingly elitist exterior - underneath that perfectly cut dinner jacket - beats the heart of a true gentleman.
BLACK TIE

items.title: Theater: ‘The Milk Train Doesn’t Stop Here Anymore’
items.description: Olympia Dukakis gives a fearless, vanity-free performance as the dying gorgon Flora Goforth in Tennessee Williams’s patchy 1963 play about the anguish and fear that can attend our going forth into the unknown (2:15).
items.author: Charles Isherwood

addresses.crossstreet: (between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue)

article.title: Olympia Dukakis in Tennessee Williams’s ‘Milk Train’ - Review
text: Total fearlessness is not a requirement for embarking on an acting career. But it is definitely a necessity for essaying the role of the dying gorgon Flora Goforth in "The Milk Train Doesn’t Stop Here Anymore," a curious, rather curdled 1963 play by Tennessee Williams.

In Olympia Dukakis, the star of the new Off Broadway revival directed by Michael Wilson at the Laura Pels Theater, the Roundabout Theater Company has found an actress with the fortitude to risk ridicule in this fitfully moving, patchily eloquent but often preposterous drama about the loneliness and fear that can attend our going forth into the great unknown. Fortunately, Ms. Dukakis also possesses the talent to make the effort worthwhile.

Strangely, her ferocious, vanity-free performance is most entrancing when most absurd. Consider the scene in which the aged Flora, ravaged by disease and drugs but still capable of mustering the coquettish vanity of the showgirl she once was, emerges to entertain a dinner guest in full kabuki regalia, swathed in a silk kimono, her matted gray hair covered by pillows of black locks.

Smiling coyly, wagging her head in persuasive mimicry of a winsome geisha, Ms. Dukakis’s Flora swoops and poses and flutters her fans before her stunned audience of one, as if performing before the imperial court of some bygone dynasty. ("Don’t tell me we’re having a Chinese dinner," cracks her bewildered visitor.) The display is at once macabre, hilarious and weirdly touching, as the frail, harsh-tempered woman who has been braying like a donkey for much of the evening is transformed into a sensual seductress.

Macabre, hilarious and weirdly touching more or less sums up Ms. Dukakis’s performance, although a host of other adjectives might also be applied to her multihued portrait of a woman who has married and buried four husbands but cannot face the truth when the reaper comes to escort her from life’s banquet.

Fortunately for Flora, a celestial usher arrives in the comely form of Christopher Flanders (Darren Pettie), a poet and sculptor of mobiles - perhaps they were fashionable in the 1960s? - who scrambles up the goat path to Flora’s Mediterranean mountaintop aerie with the mission of easing her passage into eternity. As Flora learns to her discomfort when she does some reconnaissance with a local gossip known as the Witch of Capri (Edward Hibbert, camping like there’s no tomorrow for him either), Chris has gained the nickname the Angel of Death, bestowed for his habit of arriving on the doorstep of ailing dowagers with fat purses shortly before their demise.

The role of Flora, also known as Sissy, has not served actresses particularly well. Hermione Baddeley starred in the original Broadway production, but only for the two months it ran. A rewritten version that opened less than a year later, starring Tallulah Bankhead and Tab Hunter, fared even worse, closing after only five performances. At the height of her flamboyant 1960s glamour, Elizabeth Taylor belly-flopped big-time in the hootably bad (but also hootably good) movie version, titled "Boom" (don’t ask), which featured Richard Burton, then her husband, as Chris and Noël Coward - of all people - as the Witch of Capri. (The role was written for a woman and portrayed by Mildred Dunnock in the original production.)

Ms. Dukakis does not entirely avoid shipwreck in this woozy vessel. As the mood darkens, and Flora must embrace impending death in the arms of her spiritual chaperone, things become moderately mortifying. Flora’s acerbic exchanges with her secretary, Blackie (Maggie Lacey), and the sniping Witch give way to passionate clinches with Chris and panting invitations to join her in bed.

But for two-thirds of the play Flora is amusing if abrasive company, and Ms. Dukakis invests her with a bullying bravado that commands attention even when the play’s static nature and more lurid excesses threaten to derail it. For Mr. Wilson’s production, featuring a set (by Jeff Cowie) that’s overly literal for a play poised at the blurry divide between realism and symbolism, is not always as persuasive as Ms. Dukakis’s redoubtable Flora. (Mr. Wilson, a Williams specialist, first directed the play with Ms. Dukakis as Flora at the Hartford Stage in 2008.)

With his sullen good looks and easy sexual charisma, Mr. Pettie has at least half the necessary attributes for Chris Flanders. But there is nothing of the mystic about him, and if we are to take Chris seriously as a missionary of mercy to desperate mortals at the portals of death, some spiritual aura (however ersatz) is necessary. (In Mr. Pettie’s defense, even the most luminously spiritual actor probably couldn’t make palatable floridities like Chris’s accusation that the Witch is "the heart of a world that has no heart, the heartless world we live in.")

As Blackie, to whom Flora is dictating her memoirs at all hours of the day and night, via a specially installed sound system, Ms. Lacey has the crisp efficiency and emotional reserve of the "Vassar girl" Flora derisively calls her. But the performance has a jerky quality, perhaps understandably, as Blackie moves from subjugation to defiance to sensual abandon in the arms of Chris. The wary inner warmth that might stitch the whole together never comes across.

Mr. Hibbert makes a full five-course meal of his brief scenes as the catty Witch of Capri. He, at least, is unburdened by the responsibility of any heavy lifting relating to the play’s more ponderous ideas about the lost and lonely finding solace in the gloaming. His simpering snobbishness is a continual pleasure, a well-stocked candy store of bitchery. "I can’t go back to Capri in a dinner jacket before sundown," he huffs in outrage when Flora wants to give him the heave-ho.

By no means does "Milk Train" represent Williams at his most dramatically or lyrically assured. But it is enlivened by the scabrous humor and forthright frankness (at times crudeness) about matters physical that feature in many of his later, mostly derided and little-revived plays. Flora can be seen as an older iteration of the conniving Alexandra Del Lago, a k a the Princess Kosmonopolis, of "Sweet Bird of Youth," from a few years before. (That play returns to Broadway in this, the centennial year of Williams’s birth, with Nicole Kidman in the lead role.) A worldly operator who looks on every relationship as a transaction in which she is determined to get the upper hand, Flora has a razor-blade tongue whose bloodletting is often bawdy and funny.

But while Ms. Dukakis renders with broad, almost Borscht Belt humor the vulgar aspects of the character, she shades her performance with haunting glimpses of deeper feeling, as Flora relives both the most shameful episodes in her past, like her cruel indifference to the death of her first husband, and the most ennobling, her transporting love for her last.

The spectacle of Flora’s gross but vital humanity in abject terror before its extinction cannot fail to move. Most of us are capable of cruel deeds as well as the rapture of requited love, and we will all know the terrible moment when there will be time neither to redeem the mistakes nor relive the joys.
THE MILK TRAIN DOESN’T STOP HERE ANYMORE

items.title: Theater: ‘Molly Sweeney’
items.description: This three-actor monologue play by Brian Friel, about a blind woman who undergoes an operation to give her sight, is revived in a wonderful and heartbreaking production, one that stays in the mind long after the applause ends (2:00).
items.author: Ken Jaworowski

article.title: Brian Friel’s ‘Molly Sweeney’ at Irish Rep - Review
text: It takes two hours to watch "Molly Sweeney" at the Irish Repertory Theater. But you’ll spend much more time thinking about it afterward. A deeply moving meditation on hope, change and despair, it’s a compelling piece of theater, one in which the ending applause is only the beginning of the play’s effects.

Molly, who has been blind almost since birth, starts off by recounting her life, one blessed with friends and a recent marriage. Her ever-enthusiastic husband, Frank, embarks on a plan to restore her sight and seeks out Mr. Rice, a once-promising eye surgeon who has gone into near-seclusion. "What has she to lose?" Mr. Rice asks as he agrees to operate on her. That question will haunt them all.

In the play, which had its New York premiere Off Broadway in 1996, the three characters tell their tales directly to the audience in intertwined monologues, never addressing one another. It’s a risky form, particularly in an age that worships spectacle. But Brian Friel, the playwright, is a masterly storyteller. As in his similarly structured "Faith Healer," the drama here remains strong as events unfold, leading to a play as tense as it is wonderfully written.

Just as remarkable is Mr. Friel’s tendency to force subtle shifts in words, particularly those to do with sight, which take on multiple meanings throughout the script. In the same way, stories that were told for laughs show themselves to be eerie foreshadows. It’s an uncanny feeling for an audience, when what once seemed cheerful turns chilling.

Geraldine Hughes as Molly, Ciaran O’Reilly as Frank and Jonathan Hogan as Mr. Rice handle their monologues with confidence. While at times a silence or pause would speak with more authority than words, Charlotte Moore’s direction sacrifices such moments for the sake of a steady pace. It’s an entirely reasonable, if occasionally lamentable, tradeoff.

For the careful viewer "Molly Sweeney" is an astonishing work, one that acutely examines its characters and asks us to make similar observations of ourselves. Not least important, it’s a highly entertaining play, often delivering laughs while posing its questions. Those laughs soon fade away, as laughs will. Those questions, however, stay with you.
"Molly Sweeney" continues through March 13 at the Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea; (212) 727-2737, irishrep.org.
